intro: Rubus obscurus var. cinerascens, commonly known as the gray-leafed blackberry, is a shrub native to North America. It is characterized by its dark, thorny stems and small, elliptical leaves that have a distinctive grayish-white underside. The plant produces aggregate fruits that are typically dark purple to black in color, with a slightly sour taste. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks. Due to its ornamental value and edible fruits, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
